title: Why does my wifi keep spontaneously saying 'connected but no internet access? - Quora

response.answer_text: The “Connected” status means that your computer is connected, by WiFi, to the router. In addition to connection to WiFi, you need multiple services to actually connect to the LAN, and to the Internet. Right now, I can think of a few possibilities. Authentication. Connection is the first step in using the LAN. Next comes proving that you are entitled to use the LAN. If your computer is not properly authenticated, you get no service - even if “connected”.Hardware address filter. Every different computer (phone, refrigerator, tablet, TV, watch, whatever …) in the world has a unique hardware aka MAC address. Some routers use MAC address filtering, which requires that you add each computer MAC address to a permission list before it gets connectivity.Address service aka DHCP. You can be “connected” but the router service that provides your computer an IP address can be overloaded or down. No IP address == no service.Bandwidth. You can be “connected” - but still have a poor connection. Or a neighbour (using this LAN or a different LAN) can hog the channel, leaving you with no / poor bandwidth. Your neighbour may be stealing your service - or they can have their own LAN / Internet service / WiFi using the same radio service (“channel”).ISP. Your ISP may be having problems - or your service may be off.Any or all can be a problem - even with “Connected” status displayed. This can be a lot of fun to diagnose. Do you have a second computer - or only one? It’s always easier to diagnose connectivity issues when you have multiple computers. Do you have a second computer, connected by Ethernet / fiber / whatever? It’s still more useful to remove WiFi from the problem, and diagnose. Do you have a friend or neighbour, who will let you connect to his LAN? It’s similarly useful to verify that your computer is operational. If any of this makes your head spin, it may be time to bring a local tech into the problem. Failing that, you can provide details about your LAN / WiFi / ISP here, and I’ll try to give you hints. Again, this can be a lot of fun, for people like me. Maybe not for you, though.

Imagine two areas for your WiFi - the part that is inside your house (LAN = “Local Area Network”), and the part that is outside (WAN = “Wide Area Network”). There is a “gateway” device that connects the LAN and the WAN together. This gateway can be a combination device or two separate devices. The front end is some type of “modem”. The input is your phone line in the case of a DSL Modem or a co-axial cable in the case of a Cable Modem. For a stand-alone modem, there is an output that connects to the “router”. The back end is some type of “router”. This is what your device connect to, and can be a version of 802.11 wireless Ethernet or wired Ethernet with a CAT-5 cable or a combination of the two. With a combo device, both the modem and the router are in the same physical box. Now that we have all the parts for connecting, lets get to your question … With your router turned on, your devices will be able to connect to it. This lets them communicate with each other. In that sense you are “connected”. In a combo device, if the modem part isn’t connecting to the outside world (e.g., your ISP = “Internet Service Provider”), which is the internet, then you’ll still see that your device is “connected” but there is no internet service. For separate modem + router, the router has to be connected to the modem and the modem has to be connected to the ISP. So if for whatever reason the modem is not working properly, or the ISP is not working, then your home WiFi will be connected but you won’t have any internet connection. The follow up question is then: How do I connect the home WiFi (LAN) to the Internet (WAN). And that can be a *VERY* long answer, since there are many things which can go wrong. We’ve published a 2-part (yes, I said it was long) trouble shooting guide that can help you with that. It’s too much to include in this answer, so here is the link to Part 1 - Network Connectivity Troubleshooting – Part One - and a quick bullet summary. 1.Check the power 2.Check the router 3.Check the cables 4.Reboot both router and PC 5. Check functionality 6. Test functionality 7. Check virus software 8. Try another system 9. Check ISP 10. Final options Hope that helps!
